H0.text: Erosion is the process by which today's limestone caverns, once solid rock, were formed as acidic rainwater seeped through the rock over hundreds of years and dissolved part of the rock.

H1.text: Deposition is the process by which today's limestone caverns, once solid rock, were formed as acidic rainwater seeped through the rock over hundreds of years, dissolving part of the rock.

H2.text: Physical weathering is the process by which todayâ€™s limestone caverns, once solid rock, were formed as acidic rainwater seeped through the rock over hundreds of years, dissolving part of the rock and creating the caverns.

H3.text: Chemical weathering is the process by which today's limestone caverns were formed, as acidic rainwater seeping through the rock over hundreds of years dissolved part of the rock, forming caverns.

A4.text: Carbonate dissolution takes place when rainwater combines with carbon dioxide to form carbonic acid, a weak acid, which dissolves calcium carbonate (limestone) and forms soluble calcium bicarbonate.

A5.text: Carbonate dissolution on the surface of well-jointed limestone produces a dissected limestone pavement. This process is most effective along the joints, widening and deepening them.
